problem.tex: Suppose $\gamma$ is a closed rectifiable curve in $\mathbb{C}$. Show that if $a$ and $b$ are in the same connected component of $\mathbb{C}\setminus\gamma$ then the winding numbers $n(\gamma; a)=n(\gamma; b)$.

solution.tex:
Reparametrize $\gamma$ if necessary so its domain is $[0,1]$. Recall the definition of winding number. \[n(\gamma;a)= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma rac{1}{z-a}dz= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_0^1 rac{1}{\gamma(t)-a}\gamma'(t)dt.\] Let $\gamma_1$ be the curve $\gamma_1(t)=\gamma(t)+a-b$. Then $\gamma_1'=\gamma'$ so \[\int_{\gamma_1} rac{1}{z-a}dz=\int_0^1 rac{1}{\gamma_1(t)-a}\gamma_1'(t)dt=\int_0^1 rac{1}{\gamma(t)-b}\gamma'(t)dt=2\pi i\ n(\gamma;b).\] We need to show that $\gamma$ and $\gamma_1$ are homotopic in $\mathbb{C}\setminus\{a\}$ -- the region on which $ rac{1}{z-a}$ is holomorphic. Let $G$ be the path component of $\mathbb{C}\setminus\gamma$ containing both $a$ and $b$ and let $p:[0,1]	o G$ be a path such that $p(0)=a$ and $p(1)=b$. For $s\in[0,1]$ define the shifted path $c_s(t)=\gamma(t)+a-p(s)$. Then $c_s$ is a path homotopy taking $\gamma$ to $\gamma_1$, it remains to show that $c_s(t)
eq a$ for all $s,t$. Suppose there were some $s,t$ for which $c_s(t)=a$. Then \[\gamma(t)+a-p(s)=a\] \[\gamma(t)=p(s).\] However, $p$ maps into $G\subseteq\mathbb{C}\setminus\gamma$, so $p(s)
eq\gamma(t)$ for all $s,t$. Thus $c_s(t)
eq a$ for all $s,t$. That makes $c_s$ a path homotopy from $\gamma$ to $\gamma_1$ in $\mathbb{C}\setminus\{a\}$. Then \[n(\gamma;a)= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma rac{1}{z-a}dz= rac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\gamma_1} rac{1}{z-a}dz=n(\gamma;b).\]
